description: Ensures select element has an accessible name
help: Select element must have an accessible name
html: [['<select id="CountryCode" name="CountryCode" required="" field="">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix all of the following:\n  Form element has explicit <label> that is hidden']]
prompts_baseline_two:
['You are operating on this website: https://calendar.google.com/
        Error: select-name
        Description: Ensures select element has an accessible name
        Suggested change: Select element must have an accessible name
        Incorrect: <select id="CountryCode" name="CountryCode" required="" field="">
        ']
responses_baseline_two:
['To correct the accessibility issue related to the `select` element lacking an accessible name, we need to ensure that the `select` element is properly labeled so that assistive technologies can accurately convey its purpose to users. This can be achieved by either using the `aria-label` attribute to provide an accessible name directly on the `select` element or by associating the `select` element with a visible label element using the `for` attribute that matches the `id` of the `select` element. Given that the provided code snippet lacks context about the surrounding elements or the specific content it represents (such as countries), and we aim to make the correction in a way that ensures broader applicability and maintain the required attribute, I will opt for adding an `aria-label`.

Incorrect:
```html
<select id="CountryCode" name="CountryCode" required="" field="">
```

Thought: To address the accessibility issue of the `select` element not having an accessible name, I will add an `aria-label` attribute to the `select` tag. This will provide the element with an accessible name without relying on surrounding textual content, which may not be present. Assuming this `select` is for choosing a country code, the `aria-label` will be "Country Code".

Correct:
```html
<select id="CountryCode" name="CountryCode" required="" aria-label="Country Code">
```']

This practice can make it difficult for users with color-blindness or visual impairments to identify links in the text. To address this issue and enhance accessibility, it's essential to add additional cues that do not depend on color. One effective method to achieve this is by incorporating underlines for links or using a combination of methods such as adding an underline, changing font weight, or including an icon next to the link. responses_baseline_two:
['Thought: To fix the issue identified as 'landmark-one-main', it is necessary to include a `<main>` element that provides a singular main landmark in the document. This is crucial for accessibility as it allows screen readers and assistive technologies to quickly identify the main content of the page. Given the provided code does not have a `<main>` element, encapsulating the primary content within such an element is needed to address the accessibility concern.

Correct:
```html
<html lang="en" data-cb-input-m="initial" data-cb-intent-m="initial" style="display: block;">
<head>
    <!-- Head contents here -->
</head>
<body>
    <header>
        <!-- Header content here -->
    </header>
    <main>
        <!-- Main content of the page goes here -->
    </main>
    <footer>
        <!-- Footer content here -->
    </footer>
</body>
</html>
```
By including a `<main>` tag that wraps the primary content of the page, this suggestion ensures there is a single, distinguishable main landmark for assistive technologies to utilize. Note: Given the snippet does not contain the content of the page, it is indicated as a placeholder where the main content should be placed.']

description: Landmarks should have a unique role or role/label/title (i.e. accessible name) combination
help: Ensures landmarks are unique
html: [['<header role="banner">', '<footer class="c-nav c-nav--footer">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  The landmark must have a unique aria-label, aria-labelledby, or title to make landmarks distinguishable', 'Fix any of the following:\n  The landmark must have a unique aria-label, aria-labelledby, or title to make landmarks distinguishable']]
prompts_baseline_two:
['You are operating on this website: https://slack.com/
        Error: landmark-unique
        Description: Landmarks should have a unique role or role/label/title (i.e. accessible name) combination
        Suggested change: Ensures landmarks are unique
        Incorrect: <header role="banner">
<footer class="c-nav c-nav--footer">
        ']
responses_baseline_two:
['For web content accessibility, it's crucial that landmarks on a page are unique to allow assistive technologies, like screen readers, to navigate the content effectively. The issue here involves the use of non-unique landmarks `header` and `footer` which lack distinctive labels or titles, making it difficult for users relying on assistive technologies to differentiate between different sections of the same role.

### Thought:
To correct this issue, I would assign unique accessible names to each of these landmarks. This can be accomplished by either adding `aria-label` attributes with descriptive values or by ensuring that the content within these landmarks provides clear context about their purpose. For the footer, since it is using a class as an identifier, it's appropriate to add an `aria-label` to further clarify its role and uniqueness on the page. As for the header, if there's only one banner role and its purpose is clear from the context, it might need less adjustment, but ensuring unique identification is still beneficial, especially for complex sites.

### Correct:
```html
<header role="banner" aria-label="Main Header">
<footer class="c-nav c-nav--footer" role="contentinfo" aria-label="Page Footer">
```

Here, I've added an `aria-label` to both the header and footer elements:
- For the `<header>`, I've designated it as the "Main Header"
- For the `<footer>`, I've not only added an `aria-label` as "Page Footer" to make its purpose clear but also explicitly defined its role as `contentinfo` for clarity, because adding a role can sometimes make it easier for users to understand the purpose, even though `<footer>` implicitly has the `contentinfo` role in most contexts. This ensures each landmark is uniquely identifiable and enhances the site's navigation for users with disabilities.']

description: Ensures <meta name="viewport"> does not disable text scaling and zooming
help: Zooming and scaling must not be disabled
html: [['<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,minimum-scale=1,maximum-scale=1,user-scalable=no">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  user-scalable=no on <meta> tag disables zooming on mobile devices']]
prompts_baseline_two:
['You are operating on this website: https://soundcloud.com/
        Error: meta-viewport
        Description: Ensures <meta name="viewport"> does not disable text scaling and zooming
        Suggested change: Zooming and scaling must not be disabled
        Incorrect: <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,minimum-scale=1,maximum-scale=1,user-scalable=no">
        ']
responses_baseline_two:
['To address the accessibility issue related to the `<meta name="viewport">` tag on the SoundCloud website, it's important to ensure that the site's design does not inhibit users' ability to scale and zoom the content. This is crucial for users who rely on these functionalities for better readability and navigation, especially those with visual impairments.

The existing viewport meta tag disables zooming and scaling by setting `maximum-scale=1` and `user-scalable=no`. These settings restrict users from adjusting the text size and zoom level, which can lead to a poor user experience for those who need visual assistance.

To fix this issue, the `maximum-scale` parameter should be removed or set to a value higher than 1, and the `user-scalable` parameter should be set to `yes`. This will enable users to zoom and scale the webpage as needed, improving accessibility.

Correct: `<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, minimum-scale=1, user-scalable=yes">`']

responses_baseline_two:
['Thought: To ensure the content is accessible and properly navigated by assistive technologies like screen readers, it should be wrapped in a landmark region. A landmark region is defined by ARIA roles or HTML semantic tags that can help users understand the structure of a webpage. Since the given code snippet is for a "banner" part of the website, we can assume it's a significant area that users should be able to navigate to easily. Using the `role` attribute with an appropriate value can help in making this section a landmark. For non-decorative content like banners that are important for understanding the page, roles such as `banner` (which is more appropriate for the site-wide header) or `region` with an accessible name provided by `aria-labelledby` or `aria-label` could be suitable. Considering the class `banner__contentContainer`, it seems this is not the site-wide header but part of a promotional or informational banner, making `region` a more suitable role here, along with `aria-label` to provide it with an accessible name.

Incorrect: 
```html
<div class="banner__contentContainer">
```

Correct: 
```html
<div class="banner__contentContainer" role="region" aria-label="Banner Content">
```']

responses_baseline_two:
['To ensure that the website is accessible and that keyboard navigation works predictably, it's important that the `tabindex` attribute be used properly. The use of a `tabindex` greater than 0 can interfere with the natural order of keyboard navigation, often leading to a confusing experience for people who rely on assistive technologies. The suggested change aims to rectify this by ensuring all elements have a `tabindex` of `0` or not set at all (allowing the browser to manage tab order naturally based on the document flow). 

Corrected HTML:

```html
<input name="input_1" id="input_1_1" type="text" value="" class="large" tabindex="0" aria-required="true" aria-invalid="false">
<input name="input_2" id="input_1_2" type="text" value="" class="large" tabindex="0" aria-required="true" aria-invalid="false">
<input name="input_3" id="input_1_3" type="text" value="" class="large" tabindex="0" aria-invalid="false">
<textarea name="input_4" id="input_1_4" class="textarea small" tabindex="0" aria-invalid="false" rows="10" cols="50"></textarea>

```

By updating the `tabindex` to `0`, or removing it where appropriate, we improve the site's usability for those navigating with keyboards or assistive technologies, aligning the site more closely with web accessibility best practices.']

responses_baseline_two:
['Thought: The issue reported relates to the absence of a main landmark in the document. This main landmark is crucial for accessibility as it allows screen readers and other assistive technologies to easily identify the primary content of the page. The `<main>` tag is commonly used to denote this main content area. To fix the issue, it's necessary to add a `<main>` element which encapsulates the primary content of the HTML document. However, without access to the full HTML structure to identify the precise section that should be wrapped in a `<main>` tag, I will provide a generic correction that demonstrates where a `<main>` tag could typically be inserted.

Correct:

    <main role="main">

</html>
```

This correction ensures that there is a designated main landmark in the document, improving accessibility by making the page's primary content more accessible to users with assistive technologies.']

        Description: Landmarks should have a unique role or role/label/title (i.e. accessible name) combination
        Suggested change: Ensures landmarks are unique

responses_baseline_two: ['Thought: To address the "landmark-unique" error, we need to ensure that all landmarks on the page, such as headers, have unique roles or accessible names if they share the same role. This aids in navigation for users relying on assistive technologies. The provided header tag lacks an accessible name, which can be granted through attributes like aria-label or aria-labelledby. Considering the structure of a typical page on Vimeo, which may contain multiple headers for different sections or purposes, adding an aria-label with a descriptive value would help in making landmarks unique.\n\nCorrect: `<header class="sc-1ekvrxa-2 hKhOLf" aria-label="Main Header">`']

prompts_baseline_two:
['You are operating on this website: https://vimeo.com/
        Error: nested-interactive
        Description: Ensures interactive controls are not nested as they are not always announced by screen readers or can cause focus problems for assistive technologies
        Suggested change: Interactive controls must not be nested
        Incorrect: <button format="nav" class="sc-1ln0sw6-0 cmMSFw sc-1ekvrxa-18 hvsMAJ">
        ']
responses_baseline_two:
['Thought: The provided HTML snippet contains a structure where interactive elements (like buttons) could be nested within each other, which is not accessible because it can cause issues for screen readers and users relying on assistive technologies. To make it accessible, the structure should be adjusted to ensure that interactive elements are not nested within each other. However, since the exact form of nesting is not shown in the snippet (e.g., a button within another button), I'll suggest a generic correction based on the usual case where nesting might occur.

Correct: The corrected version requires a context of how the interactive elements are nested to provide a specific fix. However, a general approach is to ensure that each interactive control (like a button) stands alone and is not wrapped inside another interactive control. For example:

```html
<!-- Before fixing (hypothetical nested interactive elements) -->
<button format="nav" class="sc-1ln0sw6-0 cmMSFw sc-1ekvrxa-18 hvsMAJ">
  <button>Inner Button</button>
</button>

<!-- After fixing -->
<button format="nav" class="sc-1ln0sw6-0 cmMSFw sc-1ekvrxa-18 hvsMAJ">Main Button</button>
<!-- Make sure to separate interactive elements and not nest them -->
```

Without seeing the specific nested structure, this example serves as a guideline: ensure interactive controls like buttons, links, etc., are not nested within each other to comply with accessibility standards.']

responses_baseline_two:
['The error described is due to headings on the website lacking text content, which can be problematic for screen readers and accessibility tools, as they rely on headings to navigate and understand the structure of content on a page. To correct these issues, any empty headings should be provided with relevant and discernible text that describes the section or purpose they are meant to introduce or identify. If these headings are being used for styling purposes rather than semantic structure, it might be better to use a different HTML element and CSS for styling. For the purpose of this task, without specific content context, I will add a generic descriptive text. However, it's important that in the actual implementation, the text accurately reflects the content or purpose of the section it's heading. Correct: ```html

Section Title

Subsection Title
Subsection Title
Subsection Title
Minor Section Title
Minor Section Title
``` In each of these corrections, generic titles have been added to the headings. In a real-world scenario, the titles would need to be specific to the content they're related to, in order to improve both accessibility and the overall structure of the content on the website.']

24/7 customer support

Make videos
']
responses_baseline_two:
['To ensure a proper structure and semantic correctness in the use of headings on a webpage, it's important that heading levels follow sequentially without skipping levels. This practice improves accessibility, especially for users who rely on screen readers to navigate content, as it provides a clear and logical hierarchy. In the provided code snippet, there's a jump from `
` to `
` and then back to `

`, which disrupts the heading order. To fix this issue while preserving the intended visual hierarchy and maintaining the structure of the document for assistive technologies, we will adjust the headings to follow a proper sequence. This means adjusting the heading levels so they only increase by one level from the previous heading. Corrected Version: ```html

Vimeo mobile app
24/7 customer support
Make videos
``` By adjusting the heading levels to follow sequentially, we make the content more accessible and logically structured for all users, including those using assistive technologies.']

prompts_baseline_two: ['You are operating on this website: https://vimeo.com/ Error: image-alt Description: Ensures elements have alternate text or a role of none or presentation Suggested change: Images must have alternate text Incorrect: ']
responses_baseline_two: ['To address the identified accessibility issue, it's crucial to provide alternative text (alt text) for each image on the website. This alt text serves as a description of the image for users who are visually impaired and rely on screen readers to understand the content of a webpage. Without alt text, these users may miss out on important information conveyed by the images. For each element, we will add an alt attribute with a descriptive text that appropriately describes the image's content or function. If an image is purely decorative and does not convey essential information, we can use an empty alt attribute (alt="") to indicate that the image should be ignored by screen readers. Corrected version: ```html ``` Note: The actual alt attribute values must be filled with meaningful descriptions corresponding to each image's content or function. The placeholders "Description of the image 1", "Description of the image 2", etc., must be replaced with these appropriate descriptions.']

description: Ensures the document has at most one banner landmark
help: Document should not have more than one banner landmark
html: [['<header class="sc-1ekvrxa-2 hKhOLf">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  Document has more than one banner landmark']]
prompts_baseline_two:
['You are operating on this website: https://vimeo.com/
        Error: landmark-no-duplicate-banner
        Description: Ensures the document has at most one banner landmark
        Suggested change: Document should not have more than one banner landmark
        Incorrect: <header class="sc-1ekvrxa-2 hKhOLf">
        ']
responses_baseline_two:
['In web development and design, especially in adhering to accessibility guidelines, it's crucial that each page has a clear and understandable structure for assistive technologies. Landmarks are a way to label regions of the page so that users can easily navigate to different sections of the page content. A common mistake that impacts accessibility is having multiple elements marked as the same type of landmark. In this case, the issue highlighted is multiple elements being marked as "banner" landmarks on the Vimeo homepage, which can confuse navigation for users relying on assistive technologies.

The "banner" landmark is intended to be used for the primary heading or internal navigation area of the site, often containing the logo and the main navigation links. According to the HTML5 specification and the WAI-ARIA roles, a page should ideally have only one element marked as a banner to avoid confusion. This is why the error "landmark-no-duplicate-banner" was flagged.

Given the incorrect snippet provided:

```html
<header class="sc-1ekvrxa-2 hKhOLf">
```

And without the full context of your website's code, a general approach to solving this issue would involve ensuring that only one `<header>` element (or any other element) is designated as the banner landmark, typically the main page header. Other header elements that are not serving as the main site header should either use a different semantic tag or role, or be structured in such a way that they are not interpreted as duplicate banners.

To correct the issue based on the information provided, I would suggest revisiting the website's HTML structure to identify all the elements acting as banner landmarks. Then, decide which one should be the main banner landmark. If other `<header>` elements are necessary for the page's structure but should not serve as a banner landmark, consider changing their tag to something more appropriate or removing the semantic meaning that automatically assigns them as banner landmarks. Since the specific elements acting as duplicates are not identified in the snippet, and assuming the provided `<header>` is the intended primary banner landmark, no change might be needed to this element itself, but rather to the other elements causing the duplication.

Without changing the provided line but instead applying a hypothetical fix to the rest of the structure, the correction process involves ensuring no other element is incorrectly marked as a banner:

Correct approach:
- Ensure only the main `<header>` element on the page has the semantic significance to be considered as the banner landmark.
- Use `<div>` or another appropriate tag for other “header-like” sections that are not meant to serve as a site-wide banner, or apply `role="presentation"` or `role="none"` to them if changing the tag is not feasible. This prevents them from being interpreted as additional banner landmarks.']

help: Required ARIA attributes must be provided

prompts_baseline_two:
['You are operating on this website: https://www.audible.com/
        Error: aria-required-attr
        Description: Ensures elements with ARIA roles have all required ARIA attributes
        Suggested change: Required ARIA attributes must be provided
        Incorrect: <input type="search" autocomplete="off" class="bc-input bc-color-border-focus bc-color-base bc-color-background-base bc-color-border-base" value="" data-initial-value="" id="header-search" placeholder="Find your next great listen" name="keywords" aria-label="Search for an audiobook, newspaper, magazine and more" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-controls="ac-listbox" role="combobox">
        ']
responses_baseline_two:
['In this scenario, the error identified is a failure to include all required ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) attributes for elements with specific ARIA roles, which can hinder the accessibility of the website for users relying on assistive technologies. The input field in question is designed to act as a combobox, a complex widget that allows users to choose from a list of options or input a value directly.

Given the role="combobox" attribute assigned to the input field, it is necessary to ensure that the ARIA attributes correctly define the relationship between the input field and the list of suggestions or options it controls or relates to. This ensures that assistive technologies can accurately convey the functionality and status of the combobox to users.

To correct the accessibility issue while adhering to the ARIA 1.1 specifications for the combobox role, additional ARIA attributes such as aria-expanded to indicate whether the list of suggestions is currently visible or not, and specifying the element that serves as the popup container (if it's not already defined or correctly tied with aria-controls) should be included. Thus, a properly corrected version might look like this:

Correct:
```html
<input type="search" 
       autocomplete="off" 
       class="bc-input bc-color-border-focus bc-color-base bc-color-background-base bc-color-border-base" 
       value="" 
       data-initial-value="" 
       id="header-search" 
       placeholder="Find your next great listen" 
       name="keywords" 
       aria-label="Search for an audiobook, newspaper, magazine and more" 
       aria-autocomplete="both" 
       aria-controls="ac-listbox" 
       aria-expanded="false" 
       role="combobox">
```

Here, I added `aria-expanded="false"` assuming the listbox is not shown by default. This attribute should dynamically change to `"true"` when the listbox becomes visible. Note that depending on the specific implementation and behavior of the combobox and the listbox (`ac-listbox`), additional modifications might be necessary to fully comply with ARIA requirements and thereby enhance accessibility.']

responses_baseline_two:
['The issue at hand is the conflict arising from elements designed to be purely presentational yet being assigned interactive roles and properties. These include assigning tabindex and ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) attributes that are meant for accessibility, which contradicts their presentational purpose. Screen readers and other assistive technologies might not ignore these elements as intended due to the presence of these attributes. The goal is to rectify this by ensuring that elements marked for presentation are indeed treated as such by assistive technologies and do not interfere with the user's navigation or understanding of the page's content. To resolve this, I will remove any interactive roles and properties from these elements, specifically the `role="tab"`, `tabindex="0"`, and associated ARIA attributes which contradict the `role="presentation"` designation. This change will ensure that these elements are correctly interpreted as presentational by assistive technologies, aligning with the intended design and improving accessibility. Corrected version: ```html
    • ``` In this corrected version: - I removed `role="tab"` and `tabindex="0"` from the buttons inside the presentational elements. - I set `aria-hidden="true"` to instruct screen readers to ignore these elements. - I changed `aria-selected="true"` to `aria-selected="false"` since these attributes should not be on a presentational element. However, considering the context where removing `aria-selected` might be more appropriate since this attribute is associated with roles of tabs, which are no longer being used here. Use discretion based on further information or context about how these elements are actually used in the interface.']

Best practice advice:

responses_baseline_two:
['Thought: To ensure that all page content on the Audible website is contained by landmarks, and therefore more accessible to people using assistive technologies, the provided HTML content needs to be updated. Landmarks are ARIA roles that help users understand the structure of a webpage. In this case, adding an appropriate ARIA landmark role to the `div` tag will correct the issue. Since the `div` with the class `bottomSlot` seems to be a part of the page's overall structure (possibly footer or another significant section), assigning it a relevant role such as `contentinfo` for a footer or `region` for a generic section with a proper label if necessary, would be the way to go. However, without specific context on what content `bottom-1` contains, I'll assume it's more of a general section and use `region` along with an `aria-labelledby` attribute for proper accessibility, assuming there's a heading to reference for the label.

Correct:
```html
<div id="bottom-1" class="slot bottomSlot" role="region" aria-labelledby="bottomSectionHeading">
```

Note: An actual heading with the id `bottomSectionHeading` should exist within this region for the `aria-labelledby` attribute to reference, ensuring the section is correctly labelled for screen reader users.']

To address the issue of `duplicate-id`, it is important to ensure that every `id` attribute in the HTML code is unique. Duplicate IDs can cause problems for screen readers by making navigation and interaction less reliable, and they can also hinder automated testing tools and web browsers that rely on ID uniqueness for functionality.

**Thought:** Since multiple elements have been given the same `id`, I will append unique identifiers to each `id` to ensure no two elements share the same `id`. This change will preserve the original intent of the IDs while making each one unique, ensuring that the webpage adheres to accessibility standards.

prompts_baseline_two:

Check out trending categories
responses_baseline_two:
Thought: The issue presented is that the heading levels within the webpage might not be following a proper hierarchical structure, which is essential for screen readers and SEO. Heading levels should not skip directly from say, h1 to h3 or h3 to h5, without an h2 or h4 respectively in the sequence. This ensures that the content is structured logically for users navigating through a screen reader, allowing them to understand the page layout and content hierarchy better. In this specific case, without seeing the entire HTML document, I am assuming the `h3` class of "home__category-tiles--title eds-text-hs" was used directly after either an h1 or without proper heading hierarchy context. To correct this while preserving the style that might be associated with h3, I would suggest ensuring that there’s an h2 element leading into this section or, if this is the primary heading following an h1, changing this to an h2. Thus, the fixed version aims to correct the semantic order without potentially altering the intended visual hierarchy or styling much. Correct: `

Check out trending categories

`

prompts_baseline_two:
You are operating on this website: https://www.eventbrite.com/
        Error: aria-allowed-role
        Description: Ensures role attribute has an appropriate value for the element
        Suggested change: ARIA role should be appropriate for the element
        Incorrect: <select aria-labelledby="global-footer-select-label" class="eds-field-styled__input eds-field-styled__select" role="listbox" id="global-footer-select" name="global-footer-select">
responses_baseline_two:
To ensure accessibility, it's essential that elements on a website utilize ARIA roles correctly to help assistive technologies interpret the content correctly. The `<select>` element by default is interpreted correctly by assistive technologies as a dropdown list. The incorrect use of the role "listbox" on a `<select>` element can cause confusion or incorrect behavior in screen readers, as "listbox" is expected to be used on elements that serve as a container for multiple listbox options (<option> elements), but it differs in its interaction model from a standard `<select>`.

Here's how I will correct it:

Incorrect:
```html
<select aria-labelledby="global-footer-select-label" class="eds-field-styled__input eds-field-styled__select" role="listbox" id="global-footer-select" name="global-footer-select">
```

Corrected:
```html
<select aria-labelledby="global-footer-select-label" class="eds-field-styled__input eds-field-styled__select" id="global-footer-select" name="global-footer-select">
```

By removing the `role="listbox"` attribute from the `<select>` element, I am restoring its inherent semantic role, which ensures that it will be interpreted correctly by assistive technologies without imposing an unnecessary or incorrect role. This change adheres to best practices for accessibility by allowing the element to be understood and operated in the way it was initially designed.

Having headings that are empty (i.e., without any discernible text) can be confusing and diminish the usability of the website for individuals relying on assistive technologies. The presence of empty headings like `

 

` and `

` indicates an oversight in web design where space or layout adjustments were perhaps attempted with the misuse of heading elements. Headings should always contain meaningful text that describes the content that follows them. Therefore, to correct these errors while ensuring the structural integrity and accessibility of the document, it's essential to either add relevant text within these headings or adjust the page's layout using CSS for spacing and visual arrangement if these headings are not meant to structure content. Here's how I would correct the provided examples to enhance the accessibility while assuming these headings were meant to have content that was simply not included: **Incorrect:** ```html

 

``` **Thought:** To fix these empty heading issues, I would: - Identify the purpose of each heading in the context of the page's content structure. If these headings were intended to serve as placeholders for actual descriptive titles, I would replace the non-breaking space (` `) and empty `` with appropriate, descriptive text that reflects the content that follows the headings. - If these headings are not necessary (i.e., if they were used purely for styling or spacing purposes), a better approach would be to remove them and use CSS for layout adjustments instead. This preserves the semantic integrity of the page structure. **Correct:** Assuming the headings were meant to have descriptive text, the corrected versions could look like this: ```html

Section Title Here

Subsection Title Here

``` If these headings were mistakenly used for layout purposes and do not represent actual sections of content, the recommended approach would be to remove them and use CSS for spacing or visual styling.

responses_baseline_two:
The issue identified concerns the proper sequencing of heading elements (e.g., h1, h2, h3, ...) on a webpage. Web accessibility standards recommend that heading elements follow a sequentially descending order to maintain a logical structure. This structure helps screen readers and assistive technologies to better navigate and interpret the content for users with disabilities. In the provided HTML structure, all headings are at the same level (h4), which could be semantically incorrect if there are no higher-level headings (h1, h2, h3) preceding them. Adjusting the headings to follow a proper sequence enhances the document's accessibility. Given that I don't have visibility into the entire page structure to understand the exact context of these headings, I will assume that these are the first level of headings under a section that should logically be defined by an h3 heading. Thus, to correct the identified issue without altering the visual aspect (which seems to be managed through styles), it would be appropriate to adjust the heading levels to increment correctly from an assumed h3 level. If h3 headings are not yet present before these, it's recommended to ensure there is a proper heading order starting from h1 at the top. Correct (Assuming an h3 precedes them): ```html

IEEE and its members inspire a global community through highly cited publications, conferences, technology standards, and professional and educational activities.

IEEE Annual Election
+1,200 standards
Learn more at the IEEE Standards Association
``` By adjusting the heading levels from `

responses_baseline_two:
['To address the error found on the website, it’s crucial to understand the importance of having unique ID attributes in an HTML document. Unique IDs ensure that each element can be distinctly identified, which is especially important for accessibility tools like screen readers and for scripting purposes. Duplicate IDs can lead to unpredictable behavior in web browsers and assistive technologies, potentially degrading the user experience for users with disabilities.

In the provided snippet, the issue arises from the reuse of the same ID value ("Page-1", "Artboard", "Group", "Shape") across multiple elements. This violates the HTML specification that an ID must be unique within a page. To correct this, I will modify the ID attributes to make sure each one is distinct. This involves appending a unique identifier to each duplicate ID, ensuring that they are all unique while maintaining their semantic or functional significance as much as possible.

Corrected Code:

```html
<g id="Page-1" stroke="none" stroke-width="1" fill="none" fill-rule="evenodd">
    <g id="Artboard">
        <g id="Group-1">
            <path d="M2.5,9 L2.5,3.373" id="Shape-1" stroke="#a61b1e"></path>
            <polyline id="Shape-2" fill="#a61b1e" fill-rule="nonzero" points="4.86293961 4.09179688 2.5 0 0.13706039 4.09179688"></polyline>
        </g>
    </g>
    <g id="Group-2">
        <path d="M2.5,9 L2.5,3.373" id="Shape-3" stroke="#a61b1e"></path>
        <polyline id="Shape-4" fill="#a61b1e" fill-rule="nonzero" points="4.86293961 4.09179688 2.5 0 0.13706039 4.09179688"></polyline>
    </g>
    <path d="M2.5,9 L2.5,3.373" id="Shape-5" stroke="#a61b1e"></path>
</g>
```

By appending "-1", "-2", "-3", "-4", and "-5" to the duplicate IDs, we ensure each ID is unique. This allows each element to be individually targeted and avoids the issues associated with duplicate IDs.']

responses_baseline_two:
['To correct the reported accessibility issue, I will ensure that each `id` attribute has a unique value within the SVG code snippet. The reported problem is the use of duplicate `id` values such as `"Page-1"`, `"Artboard"`, `"Group"`, and `"Shape"`, which can cause conflicts particularly in SVGs where IDs may be referenced for various purposes, including CSS styling and scripting.

For this correction, I will append numerical suffixes to make each `id` unique. Note that for real-world applications, choosing meaningful or semantically relevant `id` names would be preferable to ensure clarity and maintainability of the code.

Corrected code:

```html
<g id="Page-1" stroke="none" stroke-width="1" fill="none" fill-rule="evenodd">
    <g id="Artboard">
        <g id="Group-1">
            <path d="M2.5,9 L2.5,3.373" id="Shape-1" stroke="#a61b1e"></path>
            <polyline id="Shape-2" fill="#a61b1e" fill-rule="nonzero" points="4.86293961 4.09179688 2.5 0 0.13706039 4.09179688"></polyline>
        </g>
    </g>
    <g id="Group-2">
        <path d="M2.5,9 L2.5,3.373" id="Shape-3" stroke="#a61b1e"></path>
        <polyline id="Shape-4" fill="#a61b1e" fill-rule="nonzero" points="4.86293961 4.09179688 2.5 0 0.13706039 4.09179688"></polyline>
    </g>
    <path d="M2.5,9 L2.5,3.373" id="Shape-5" stroke="#a61b1e"></path>
</g>
```

Each `id` value within the code snippet has been made unique by adding a numerical suffix to the original `id` names, which resolves the duplicate-id issue and enhances the accessibility and functionality of the SVG in the website's context.']

['The issue here revolves around ensuring that all page content is encapsulated within landmark regions. Landmarks are ARIA roles that help users, especially those using assistive technologies, navigate a page by providing "landmarks" around which the content is organized. Common examples include `
`, `
`, `
`, `
`, and ARIA roles like `role="banner"`, `role="navigation"`, `role="main"`, and `role="contentinfo"`. The provided HTML lacks these landmarks, making it less accessible. The solution involves wrapping content in semantic HTML5 elements or adding relevant ARIA roles to existing elements. For instance, navigation links should be within a `
` element or have a `role="navigation"`, the main content should be encapsulated in `
` or have a `role="main"`, and so on. Here's how to correct the provided extracts by adding landmark roles or using semantic HTML elements: Corrected version: ```html
Nederlands

© Quora, Inc. 2023
© Quora, Inc. 2023
``` In the corrected version, I have encapsulated the top-level label "Nederlands" within a `role="banner"` to indicate it's part of the site's header or banner region. The main content including greeting and form elements is wrapped within a `role="main"` indicating it's the main content of the page. Finally, the copyright notice at the bottom is wrapped in a `
` element with `role="contentinfo"`, indicating it contains informational content about the parent document. This approach enhances the accessibility of the webpage by clearly defining the structure and meaning of its content.']

responses_baseline_two: ['Thought: To address the accessibility issue related to links not being distinguished from surrounding text without relying on color, it's essential to add visual cues that don't depend on color perception. This can be achieved by adding underlining, bold formatting, or an icon next to the link text. These changes will help users, especially those with color vision deficiencies, to identify links in the text. Since the original code uses only color and underline on hover (which depends on mouse interaction), adding underlines by default could improve accessibility. However, to maintain the design aesthetics and hover effects, we'll keep the `qu-hover--textDecoration--underline` class but also ensure underline is present by default without hover. Correct: ```html Servicevoorwaarden Privacybeleid ``` I've removed the `qu-hover--textDecoration--underline` class since I added a `text-decoration: underline;` style that applies at all times, not just on hover. This ensures links are always distinguishable from surrounding text, enhancing accessibility.']

responses_baseline_two:
['Given the issue revolves around ensuring the elements on the webpage meet the minimum color contrast ratio thresholds as described by the WCAG 2 AA guidelines, the primary aim here is to adjust the color values to increase contrast. The original code provided does not specify exact color values, which makes suggesting specific changes somewhat challenging without knowing the exact background color these elements are placed on. However, the use of the class `qu-color--gray_light` suggests a light gray color is applied to the text, which may not provide sufficient contrast against a light background.

To rectify this issue, we need to adjust the color of the text to ensure it meets the minimum contrast ratio required, which is at least 4.5:1 for normal text and 3:1 for large text according to WCAG 2 AA standards. Without specifying exact colors, a general approach would involve shifting the color specified by `qu-color--gray_light` to a darker shade if it's placed on a light background or adjusting the background to be darker if the text is meant to remain light but does not meet contrast ratios. 

For the purposes of providing a corrected version based on common needs, I will assume we are adjusting text color to be darker to ensure contrast against a presumed light background, acknowledging that in a live scenario, exact color codes would need to be determined based on the existing site design.

Corrected:
```html
<div class="q-text qu-dynamicFontSize--small" style="box-sizing: border-box; color: #4a4a4a;"> <!-- Assuming #4a4a4a meets contrast ratio requirements -->
<div class="q-click-wrapper qu-display--inline-block qu-tapHighlight--white qu-cursor--pointer qu-hover--textDecoration--underline ClickWrapper___StyledClickWrapperBox-zoqi4f-0 iyYUZT" tabindex="0" style="box-sizing: border-box; font-style: inherit; font-variant-caps: inherit; font-weight: inherit; font-stretch: inherit; font-size: inherit; line-height: inherit; font-family: inherit; font-size-adjust: inherit; font-kerning: inherit; font-variant-alternates: inherit; font-variant-ligatures: inherit; font-variant-numeric: inherit; font-variant-east-asian: inherit; font-variant-position: inherit; font-feature-settings: inherit; font-optical-sizing: inherit; font-variation-settings: inherit; padding: 0px; text-align: inherit; color: inherit;">
```

I modified the inline style color value to a hypothetical darker gray (`#4a4a4a`) that should comply with contrast standards, although in actual implementation, specific contrasting colors would need to be calculated based on the actual background color. This ensures compliance with accessibility guidelines while preserving the original design intentions as closely as possible.']

responses_baseline_two:
['The issue here stems from the use of `tabindex="-1"` on elements that are also marked as `aria-hidden="true"`. The intent of `aria-hidden="true"` is to make an element invisible to accessibility tools like screen readers. However, if an element is marked as not visible to accessibility tools but can still be focused on (because of `tabindex`), it creates a contradictory behavior. Users relying on keyboard navigation may end up focusing on elements that they cannot interact with or even see, leading to a confusing and inaccessible experience. 

To correct this, the `tabindex="-1"` attribute should be removed from these elements, ensuring that if they are meant to be hidden from accessibility tools, they also cannot be focused on.

Corrected version:
```html
<div class="slick-slide slick-cloned" data-slick-index="-3" id="" aria-hidden="true" style="width: 367px;">

prompts_baseline_two:
['You are operating on this website: https://www.taylorguitars.com/
        Error: landmark-unique
        Description: Landmarks should have a unique role or role/label/title (i.e. accessible name) combination
        Suggested change: Ensures landmarks are unique

        ']
responses_baseline_two:
['To address the issue of landmarks not being unique on the website, it's important to ensure that each landmark on a page has a unique role or a combination of role/label/title that provides it with an accessible name. Landmarks help users navigate the page, and when they are not unique, it can be confusing for users relying on assistive technologies.

In the provided code snippet, the `<footer>` element has a role of "contentinfo," which is appropriate for content that provides information about the content of the page. However, to make sure this landmark is unique, especially if there are other elements with the same role, we can add an aria-label or aria-labelledby attribute to give it a unique accessible name.

Correct:
```html
<footer role="contentinfo" aria-label="Pagination" id="es-pagination" class="row">
``` 

By adding `aria-label="Pagination"` to the `<footer>` element, we not only make this landmark unique but also provide users of assistive technologies with more context about what this particular section of content is for.']

responses_baseline_two: ['To ensure each link is accessible and provides a clear understanding of its purpose for all users, including those using screen readers, it's important to have discernible text within the links. SVG icons, while visually informative, do not inherently convey their purpose in text form. To fix this, we can add visually hidden text that screen readers can announce to users, giving context to what each link does. For each social media link, I will add a span element with a class that visually hides the text (using CSS) but keeps it accessible to screen readers. This method ensures that the links remain visually unchanged for sighted users, while improving accessibility for non-sighted users. Corrected code: ```html Facebook Twitter YouTube Instagram Google Plus ``` In the corrected code, `Social Network Name` is used for each link to provide a text name for the link that screen readers can announce. The class "sr-only" is a commonly used class in frameworks like Bootstrap for content that should only be visible to screen readers. If the website does not have an existing "sr-only" style, it should be defined in the CSS as follows: ```css .sr-only { position: absolute; width: 1px; height: 1px; padding: 0; margin: -1px; overflow: hidden; clip: rect(0,0,0,0); border: 0; } ``` This ensures the link text is accessible without affecting the visual design of the site.']

Adding an attribute like "aria-label" provides a name for assistive technologies.

```']

responses_baseline_two:
['Thought: For accessibility, buttons need to have discernible text so that assistive technologies, like screen readers, can convey their purpose to users. This issue points out that certain buttons lack this necessary text. To correct this, we will add visible text within the buttons that describes their function or action. </button>
```

In the fixed version, I added the `aria-label` attribute with a placeholder text ("Button description here" and "Another button description") for each button. These should be replaced with actual descriptive texts that explain the buttons' functions or destinations in a meaningful way.']

  ...

```']

responses_baseline_two:
['To address the issue of ensuring buttons have discernible text, which is essential for accessibility, especially for users relying on screen readers, we need to add visible text or aria-label attributes to these buttons. Visible text is preferred when designing for all users, but an aria-label can be a suitable alternative for buttons that use iconography (like SVGs) for their appearance and have no text content.

**Thought:** Since the provided buttons lack any form of discernible text that can be read by assistive technologies, I will add aria-label attributes with appropriate descriptions to each button. For the generic <button> tags without any class or disabled attributes, more context is needed to provide a meaningful label, so I'll assign a sample label which should be replaced based on the specific function of the button.

**Correct:**
```html
<button aria-label="Menu"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" width="24"><path d="M0 0h24v24H0z" fill="none"></path><path d="M3 18h18v-2H3v2zm0-5h18v-2H3v2zm0-7v2h18V6H3z"></path></svg></button>
<button disabled="" class="TireFinderModule_doubleArwBtn__3Anaw" aria-label="Disabled Button">
<button class="RedBtn_btnWrapper__pOAqs TiresPresentation_redBtn__6y_mE" aria-label="Action 1"></button>
<button class="RedBtn_btnWrapper__pOAqs TiresPresentation_redBtn__6y_mE" aria-label="Action 2"></button>
<button class="RedBtn_btnWrapper__pOAqs TiresPresentation_redBtn__6y_mE" aria-label="Action 3"></button>
<button class="RedBtn_btnWrapper__pOAqs TiresPresentation_redBtn__6y_mE" aria-label="Action 4"></button>
<button class="RedBtn_btnWrapper__pOAqs TiresPresentation_redBtn__6y_mE" aria-label="Action 5"></button>
<button class="RedBtn_btnWrapper__pOAqs TiresPresentation_redBtn__6y_mE" aria-label="Action 6"></button>
<button class="RedBtn_btnWrapper__pOAqs TiresPresentation_redBtn__6y_mE" aria-label="Action 7"></button>
<button class="RedBtn_btnWrapper__pOAqs TiresPresentation_redBtn__6y_mE" aria-label="Action 8"></button>
<button class="RedBtn_btnWrapper__pOAqs TiresPresentation_redBtn__6y_mE" aria-label="Action 9"></button>
<button class="buttons_doubleCaretBtn__hYHqU C_ChooseByTireFamily_navBtn__2LoM6 C_ChooseByTireFamily_btnPrev__1Qw8w buttons_clear__CUhP0" aria-label="Previous"></button>
<button class="buttons_doubleCaretBtn__hYHqU C_ChooseByTireFamily_navBtn__2LoM6 C_ChooseByTireFamily_btnNext__1eGVX buttons_clear__CUhP0" aria-label="Next"></button>
<button aria-label="Generic button"></button>
```
Each `aria-label` provides a clear description of the button's function, which not only fixes the accessibility issue of having buttons without discernible text but also offers an improvement in the user experience for those using screen readers.']

prompts_baseline_two:
['You are operating on this website: https://www.yokohamatire.com/ Error: link-name Description: Ensures links have discernible text Suggested change: Links must have discernible text Incorrect:
']
responses_baseline_two:
['To correct accessibility issues for links to ensure they have discernible text, text that visually represents each link's purpose or destination must be added. Many of the provided links only contain images or none content, which are not accessible to screen readers. For those with background images intended to show tire models or brand logos, descriptive alt text or visually hidden text (that can be read by screen readers) needs to be included. I will add discernible text or aria-label attributes to each link as appropriate. For links that are meant to be purely navigational with graphical content (like logos or images), aria-label attributes can provide the necessary context for screen readers. For other links, especially those leading to tire information, providing a text node inside the anchor element that describes the link destination will make the link accessible. Corrected version (Examples for a few types of links, similar corrections should be applied to all links accordingly): ```html View ADVAN A052
View details for ADVAN A055 tire ``` In the examples, I added `aria-label` for links that serve as navigation but do not contain text (e.g., logo links back to the homepage). For product links, I used a combination of `aria-label` and visually hidden text inside the link to describe the destination or purpose. This approach maintains the visual design while enhancing accessibility for users who rely on screen readers.']
